facts.text: Har Narain obtained a decree from the court of the Additional Munsif, Ghaziabad, against Sunehri Jogi for a sum of money.
In execution of the decree, the Munsif issued a warrant for attachment of judgment-debtor's property. Amin attached three buffaloes and two cows in the house of judgment-debtor Sunehri Jogi.
Amin kept the cattle in custody of sapurdar Chhajju, who due to lack of accommodation kept them overnight in the enclosure of decree-holder Har Narain with his permission.
On June 1, 1955 at about 7 a.m., nine appellants armed with lathis went to enclosure of decree-holder, untied two attached buffaloes.

Decree-holder Har Narain, his son Om Prakash, nephew Jhandu and Qabul protested; appellants struck them with lathis; when PW4 intervened, struck him also. Appellants 1,2,3 took away two buffaloes, others followed.

Defence version: On June 1, 1955 at 7 a.m., appellant 1 Tika taking his two buffaloes for grazing; Har Narain and 11 others with amin forcibly snatched them; assaulted Tika; when appellant 2 Raja Ram came, assaulted him; Tika and Raja Ram used lathis in self-defence.
Sessions Judge held cattle attached evening of May 31, 1955, kept in house of Har Narain; disbelieved defence that incident at 11 a.m. on June 1 in self-defence.
Tika (appellant 1) filed claim petition subsequent to incident, which was allowed; in claim petition did not question validity of attachment but set up title to buffaloes.
PW1 amin deposed attached cattle from house of Sunehri Jogi, prepared attachment list, warrant with him; no cross-examination on defects in warrant or manner of attachment.
Sessions Judge convicted appellants under ss. 147, 424, 452, 325 r/w 149, 323 r/w 149 IPC.
Allahabad High Court dismissed appeal, confirmed convictions and sentences but directed sentences to run concurrently.

legal_issues.text: Whether attachment of buffaloes was illegal, so appellants did not commit offence u/s 424 IPC by taking away their own buffaloes.
Even if attachment valid, whether amin had authority to keep attached buffaloes with sapurdar, and sapurdar with decree-holder, making decree-holder's possession illegal, so no offence u/s 424 IPC.
Whether appellants committed criminal trespass u/s 441 IPC, lacking intention to commit offence or cause annoyance, but only to recover buffaloes from illegal custody.
Whether appellants committed offence u/s 325 r/w ss. 147 and 149 IPC, as common object was not to cause grievous hurt but only to recover buffaloes.

petitioner_arguments.text: Attachment illegal, so taking away own buffaloes from decree-holder's possession not offence u/s 424 IPC.
Even if valid attachment, amin no authority to entrust sapurdar, sapurdar no power to keep with decree-holder; decree-holder's possession illegal; taking buffaloes not offence u/s 424 IPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: O. XXI r. 43 CPC; Allahabad HC r. 116

petitioner_arguments.text: No offence u/s 441 IPC as no intention to commit offence or annoy decree-holder; entered only to recover buffaloes from illegal custody.
No offence u/s 325 r/w ss. 147, 149 IPC; common object only to recover buffaloes, not cause grievous hurt.

court_reasoning.text: Attachment validly made; no challenge in claim petition or cross-examination of amin; presume regular.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proceed on assumption attachment valid in compliance with law.

court_reasoning.text: Valid attachment of movables by actual seizure vests possession in court; sapurdar or bailee (decree-holder) holds court's possession.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Decree-holder's custody as bailee of sapurdar is court's possession.

court_reasoning.text: Owner removing attached property causes wrongful gain to self (not legally entitled) and wrongful loss to court u/ss. 23,24 IPC; dishonest removal u/s 424 IPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Attachment transfers legal possession to court; owner cannot take by force.

court_reasoning.text: Entered with intent to remove cattle (offence u/s 424), so guilty u/s 441 IPC (house-trespass).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Intent to commit offence u/s 424 constitutes criminal trespass.

court_reasoning.text: Charge defect in not specifying knowledge of s.325 likelihood u/s 149; but no failure of justice u/s 537 CrPC; accused knew case, evidence proved knowledge grievous hurt likely.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence shows common object to recover cattle involved force causing grievous hurt.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished/overruled cases where attachment illegal or different law (larceny); followed cases where legal attachment, owner guilty u/ss.379/424 IPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Owner must file claim petition, not use force.

holdings.text: Legal attachment vests possession in court; owner removing by force causes wrongful gain/loss, guilty u/s 424 IPC.
Sapurdar's entrustment to decree-holder as bailee maintains court's possession.
Entry to commit s.424 offence constitutes s.452 IPC.
Conviction u/s 325 r/w 149 valid despite charge defect; no failure of justice.

precedents_cited.relevance: Larceny requires property of another; inapplicable to IPC theft/dishonest removal.
Owner removing attached crops not dishonest; ignored court possession.
Legal attachment transfers possession; removal dishonest u/s 379 IPC.
Owner cannot take attached property from sapurdar without court recourse; dishonest.
Attachment passes possession to court; taking away dishonest u/s 379 IPC.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Convictions under ss.147,424,452,325/149,323/149; dishonest removal requires intent for wrongful gain/loss; trespass with intent to commit offence.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Charge defect not vitiate unless failure of justice.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Mode of attachment of movables; custody rules for livestock.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, upheld High Court judgment confirming Sessions Judge's convictions under ss.147,424,452,325 r/w 149, 323 r/w 149 IPC; sentences to run concurrently as directed by High Court.

key_quotes.text: "Attachment by actual seizure involves a change of possession from the judgment-debtor to the court and the rule deals only with the liability of the attaching officer to the court."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Would the owner of a thing in court's custody have the intention of causing wrongful gain or wrongful loss within the meaning of s. 23 of the Indian Penal Code?"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Where a property has been legally attached by a court, the possession of the same passes from the owner to the court or its agent."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It can never be lawful for a person, even if he is the owner of an animal, to take it away after attachment from the person to whom it is entrusted without recourse to the court."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes State v. Rama; justifies criminality.
